metadata.title: Creation of a vascular surgical Hub responding to the COVID-19 emergency: the italian USL Toscana Centro model

body_text.text: The recent spreading of the COVID-19 pandemic in Italy led to the urgency of finding sustainable models to face the rapid increase of symptomatic hospitalized patients, while protecting non-infected patients and health-care workers from the contagion. A fair number of reports described already the efforts of health-care Institutions from different Countries to relocate wards, intensive care units (ICUs), and operating rooms (OR) to avoid the rapid collapse of the hospital facilities.1, 2, 3, 4, 5 Herein, we would like to share the protocol developed by the USL (Unità Sanitaria Locale) Toscana Centro for the reorganization of the Vascular Surgery Unit during the COVID-19 emergency.

The USL Toscana Centro is a public italian health-care institution including four districts (Empoli, Florence, Pistoia, Prato) with 13 different hospitals, serving more than 1.500.000 people in a 5000 km2 area.

The aim of a Health regional service should be to create a non- COVID-19 hospital (if possible) where elective critical surgical activity should be spared, and this model was followed also in the USL Toscana Centro during the first weeks of the epidemic. COVID-19 patients were firstly admitted in those Hospitals where ICU units and/or infectious disease wards were present. However, due to the outbreak and the overwhelming amount of COVID-19 patients needing hospitalization during the following weeks, it was not possible also in our region to preserve one or more hospitals from the disease (Figure 1
), and all 13 hospitals are now COVID-19 as first days of April passed (Italy lockdown started March, 9th with none COVID-19 patients in our hospital). Our Hospital in Florence (San Giovanni di Dio Hospital) has more than 80 COVID-19 patients in different settings (ICU, medical and surgical ward) at the time of writing, almost 1/3 of the total hospital capacity (80/260 beds). Since the beginning of the epidemic the scenario has been completely different each new week, and it was not possible to plan elective activity even day by day.

What to do therefore? Areas previously dedicated to different activities were converted to COVID-19 wards and adjunctive ICUs, and medical staff from other specialties was converted to COVID staff to ensure 24/7 patients assistance. The elective surgical and office activity was dramatically reduced in all of the centers and reserved to priority cases. In our hospital only, 4 out of 11 operating rooms are now usable: 1 for urgency/emergency, 1 for only COVID patients, 1 hybrid room, 1 for elective cases. These reduced number of ORs should accommodate 5 different specialties at the same time: urology, general surgery, orthopedy, gynecology, and finally vascular surgery. Regarding Vascular Surgery reorganization, we decided to cut all varicose vein surgery, and all office activities (apart urgencies). Aneurysm, symptomatic carotid, CLI, hemodialysis AV access surgeries were centralized in our hospital, collecting those cases from peripheral hospitals which were overwhelmed by COVID-19 patients. Endovascular treatment of CLI was preferred over bypass surgery in order to eliminate the presence of the anesthetist in the OR due to their shortage in number (many patients to be followed-up in ICUs and some anesthetists are at the time of writing unfortunately infected). Asymptomatic carotid lesions evaluated at high risk of stroke were started to be operated by our vascular staff in a private hospital which began to cooperate to the National Health System to help in this emergency situation. The drop of elective vascular surgical repair was around 34% if we compare March 2019 to March 2020. On the same way, the number of office visits dropped off around 80%.

Urgent cases of hemodynamically stable COVID-19 confirmed or suspected patients from peripheral hospitals were centralized in the dedicated COVID-19 surgical Hub of the operating block of the San Giovanni di Dio Hospital, Florence. A corner of the whole operating block, well separate from the remaining ORs, was rapidly converted into one operating room and six ICU beds dedicated to COVID patients (Figure 2
). The COVID-19 surgical path now includes an emergency room for suspected COVID-19 patients directly connected to an elevator for the transfer of COVID patients in the COVID operating block. Surgical operators access a dressing room first, where they dress up with the obligatory personal protective equipment (PPE), including: N95 mask, goggles, face shield, splash-resistant gown, boot covers and two pairs of surgical gloves. Then, the operators transfer to the COVID-19 area and into the operating room. The application of an alcoholic solution on the second pair of gloves, followed by a sterile gown and an extra pair of sterile surgical gloves complete the surgical dressing. After the intervention, the surgical operators transfer to the undressing room located besides the OR and execute the undressing procedure supervised by a trained operator. All the surfaces of the operating room are decontaminated after the intervention.

Postoperative care of COVID treated patients is a further challenge for health personnel since the high risk of cross-contagion. In order to decrease this risk, it is advisable to have two doctors visiting COVID patients: one “uncontaminated” waiting outside a closed room where patients are and one “contaminated” doctor wearing all the PPEs visiting the patients. A clear line on the floor should be drawn to separate the clean from the contaminated field (Figure 3
). We would like to report as example two cases, a ruptured AAA and a ruptured TAAA, occurred in a peripheral COVID hospital which was completely overwhelmed by COVID-19 patients with no bed left in ICU. The AAA patient was hemodynamically unstable so it was treated in the peripheral hospital and then transferred to the Hub ICU and then successfully discharged to a standard surgical ward. The hemodynamically stable covered rupture of a type II TAAA was transferred to the Hub hospital and treated by endovascular means as a COVID patient while wainting for the results of the COVID-19 test. The patient was kept isolated in the OR until the negative response of testing and was then transferred to the surgical ward.

In our experience until now testing the COVID-19 surgical Hub, the most crucial point of the creation of a well-working model is the support and the correct use of the Telemedicine infrastructure. During the last decade, one of the main goals of the USL was to implement an organization chart encouraging the share of health-care professionals between all the facilities of the territorial network. Well established Telemedicine and surgical centralization protocols were already implemented before the outbreak of the COVID-19 epidemic, allowing a fast response of the USL to the massive modification of the infrastructural needs required to face the disease. The rapid communication between the accepting hospital and the Hub center has to be as fast as possible, with rapid sharing of the clinical status and of the vascular imaging of the patient (when available) to reduce the time for decision making and to plan the most efficacious treatment option for the patient.

Another key point is to provide turnover for the exhausted medical personnel. Regarding our unit, some surgeons, due to a certain “unit hypertrophy” of the vascular staff related to the current reduced vascular activity, have been temporally assigned to help anesthetists in the ICUs, or internist doctors in medical wards. Surgeons have also been placed at home for some days alternately to preserve a pool of non-infected operators that could be used in any moment in case of necessity and kept healthy on the other hand to replace infected colleagues of any specialty, since the high contagiousness of the virus.
Another scenario, in case of an uncontrolled outbreak, would be to close all elective cases and take care of urgent/emergent cases only as a Hub and Spoke service.

The last step, when the outbreak will finally come to an end, and the number of patients hospitalized will be reduced, the goal will be to gradually re-open activities. In our opinion, first of all a clear separation between COVID and non-COVID hospitals should be realized. For that purpose, it should be mandatory a testing of all admitted patients. Elective surgery should favor AAAs or TAAAs larger than 7 cm, symptomatic or vulnerable carotid lesions, AV fistulas and CLI. During this outbreak we also recruited angiologists to help us in office duties to preserve surgeons from the contagion, as previously described, but also to help us with the overwhelming number of visits postponed when this crisis will come to an end.

In conclusion, rapid decision, rapid modification of hospital settings transforming surgical ward into a medical one, ORs and medical wards into ICUs, a certain “flexibility” of the medical personnel, a stepwise shutdown of vascular surgical and office activity and the necessity of a strong leadership are mandatory to cope with the tsunami of the COVID-19 outbreak.
